front.div:
Abstract
Identification of patterns in analytical chemical data and interpretation of observed differences is
a frequent task for forensic chemists. A fiber examiner might perform UV/visible
microspectrophotometry on known and questioned fibers to evaluate possible associations
between source and location. Multivariate statistics enable confirmation of statistical validity of
discrimination between different polymer classes and dyed textile fibers, visualization of
significant differences between groups of spectra discrimination, and tracking of spectral
changes with environmental changes. The fibers and associated spectra in the database, in
combination with validated computer programs, represent an extensible tool for fiber
comparisons in casework and should also be of value in quality control and training of analysts.
In this paper, the application of linear discriminant analysis to a data base of over 5,000
UV/visible absorbance and fluorescence spectra is described.
